message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of coarse hair growth, oily skin, acne, and deepening of the voice suggests virilization, and the firm, enlarged ovary indicates an ovarian tumour. Among the options, Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour is most commonly associated with virilization. Thecoma and Granulosa cell tumours may also cause virilization, but they are usually associated with estrogen production, leading to abnormal uterine bleeding. Adrenocortical carcinoma may also cause virilization, but it usually presents with other symptoms like abdominal pain, weight loss, and hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with physical changes including unwanted hair growth, oily skin, and acne, as well as changes in external genitalia such as a deepening voice, weight gain, and an enlarged clitoris. These symptoms suggest an androgen-secreting tumor, and among the options, Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is associated with the symptoms described. Thecoma is typically associated with excess estrogen secretion, adrenocortical carcinoma presents with Cushing's syndrome, and granulosa cell tumors are typically associated with irregular periods or postmenopausal bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hyperandrogenism, and the enlarged left ovary points towards an androgen-secreting tumour. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour is a rare form of ovarian tumour that causes hyperandrogenism and virilization in females.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has hyperandrogenism, which is characterized by the excessive production of androgens. The presence of dark coarse stubbles, changes in external genitalia, and an enlarged left ovary all point to Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor as the most likely diagnosis. Thecoma or Adrenocortical carcinoma may also cause hyperandrogenism but are less likely due to the absence of specific symptoms. Granulosa cell tumour may present with similar symptoms but is typically associated with estrogen production.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of unwanted hair growth, acne, voice deepening, weight gain, and changes in external genitalia suggest virilization. The firm, enlarged left ovary suggests a possible ovarian tumor. Among the options, Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is the most likely cause of virilization in females.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of hirsutism, acne, voice deepening, and clitoromegaly suggest the most likely diagnosis is Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, a rare ovarian neoplasm that can produce androgens. Thecoma can produce estrogen, while Adrenocortical carcinoma and Granulosa cell tumor can also affect hormone production but do not typically present with the same symptoms. The enlarged left ovary is also consistent with a Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperandrogenism, which is a condition that occurs when the body produces too much androgen, a male hormone. The enlarged left ovary suggests a tumor, and among the options, Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is most likely to cause this condition. Thecoma and Granulosa cell tumors can also cause hyperandrogenism, but they do not typically present with enlarged ovaries. Adrenocortical carcinoma is not a likely cause of this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of unwanted hair growth, acne, deepening of voice, weight gain, and changes in external genitalia, along with an enlarged ovary suggest a Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor. All other options do not fit with the symptoms mentioned.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hyperandrogenism, which is associated with Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour. Other options are less likely to cause the symptoms listed. The firm, enlarged ovary also supports the diagnosis of Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of unwanted hair growth, acne, and a deepening of voice is suggestive of hirsutism, which could be caused by an androgen-secreting tumor. The combination of a clitoris measuring 12 mm long and a firm, enlarged ovary suggests a Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, which is an androgen-secreting ovarian tumor. Thecoma and granulosa cell tumors can present with similar symptoms but do not typically cause hirsutism. Adrenocortical carcinoma is possible but less likely given the enlarged ovary.
